prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my older brother that he has an obligation to help with the funeral of our abusive dad?
Our dad mellowed out quite a bit after I was born but back when my brother Jeff was younger, he was a real prick, as Jeff would put it. 

Jeff said Dad would knock him around when he drank (which was all the time), would constantly yell and berate both him and Mom, and was just an all around shitty human. 

I’m not sure what happened when I was born but dad mellowed out a lot after I was born. Growing up, I could definitely see flashes of who he was, especially when he interacted with Jeff, but all of these things Jeff described never happened with me. Jeff moved out as soon as he turned 18 and I was only 13 and he’s never looked back. 

I know that he got sober not long after my birth so I’m sure that was part of it. My mom told me stories of how he treated them back in the day too so I know it wasn’t entirely Jeff’s imagination. Although why she stayed with him, I guess was a factor of the abuse. 

Well, Dad died of a stroke last month and Mom & I have been trying to get together arrangements for his funeral. Mom has been really distraught, not only because of his death, but the fact that Jeff isn’t helping at all with the funeral planning. 

She asked me one day if I could go over to his place and convince him to be a part of the funeral. 

I went over to his place the other day and I told him that he is making Mom super upset by not helping with the funeral and that I get that he has a lot of shit to deal with because of dad but that he needs to stop being such a dick to mom. 

He went off on me then. Starting calling me an idiot, saying that I was lucky that dad never treated me the way he treated him, that I would never understand what dad put him through and then that under no circumstances will he help with “that asshole’s” funeral.  He told me to get the fuck out of his house and I didn’t want to cause any more problems so I left. 

I haven’t told mom yet what happened because I feel like I’m caught between two places. On the one hand I feel for Mom, but I also understand kind of why Jeff doesn’t want to help. 

So AITA for telling Jeff that he needs to contribute to the funeral for Mom’s sake?



"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to figure this out. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for telling their brother he should help with the funeral of their abusive dad. 

First, the situation: The dad was abusive to Jeff, the older brother, especially when he was drinking. After the younger sibling was born, the dad mellowed out. Jeff left home at 18 and hasn't been in touch. Now, the dad died, and the mom is upset because Jeff isn't helping with the funeral. The author went to Jeff's house to convince him to help for Mom's sake. Jeff was angry, called the author an idiot, and refused to help.

So, the question is whether the author was wrong to tell Jeff he should help. Let's break it down.

The author's reasoning was that Jeff should help for Mom's sake. But Jeff has a history of being abused by their dad. The author was not subjected to the same abuse, so maybe they don't fully understand Jeff's feelings. However, the author was trying to mediate between the mom and Jeff. 

Is it wrong to ask someone to participate in a funeral for a parent they had a bad relationship with? Well, there's a difference between cultural obligations and personal boundaries. In some cultures, family obligations are important, but in others, people might choose not to participate in a funeral if they have unresolved trauma. 

The author's intention was to help the mom, which is understandable. But Jeff's refusal could be due to his own trauma. The author might not have considered that Jeff could be in a place where he can't emotionally handle the funeral. 

However, the author did approach Jeff calmly, explained Mom's feelings, and tried to reason with him. Jeff's response was hostile, which complicates things. The author isn't necessarily in the wrong for trying to mediate. 

But maybe the author overstepped by implying Jeff had an obligation. Jeff might feel that the family didn't support him during the abuse, so why should he help now? The author might not have considered that angle. 

On the other hand, the author's mom is hurt and needs support. The author wanted to help her by involving Jeff. It's a tough spot. 

In conclusion, while Jeff's reaction was harsh, the author's actions were based on concern for the mom. The author isn't wrong for trying to reach out, even if Jeff didn't take it well. The key is that the author's intent was to help, and Jeff's refusal is his choice. So the answer might be B (Not in the wrong).
